So there is a lot going on so we will touch on that.
We are going to write an assignment operator, so I will show you a wrong way to do it then we can talk about what's wrong with it.
What does return *this mean?
Remember that *this only means something if you are inside of a member function of a class.
Otherwise this has no meaning, because what is this?
This is always going to be a pointer to the current instance of an object if you are inside of that object.
If you are in a member function of an object this is going to be initialized to point at the object on which that method is being called.
So return *this means return the current object.
So in the assignment operator we return the current object when we are done assigning into it and the reason for that is you can chain assignments.
I don't recommend it but you can.
That equal operator needs to return something for that last assignment to be valid.
a = b = c should assign b into c and then return the b that's been assigned and then assign that into a.
So you need to return something out of it.
Again, we'll hit on that in the actual lecture so don't worry about that to much.

That's fine as long as it is in the header
If it is in the definition I need to actually have the variables that I'm referring to.
If I don't give it a name It will still compile but  I can't refer to my argument anymore.
In the header file it is fine to omit the name of the parameter.
Because you are not using it there.
It's not a typo it is ok.

So when I really need that extra 3 pixels, I'm going to try and omit parameter names. It's not actually a bug.
